item.title: Elon Musk Completes $44 Billion Deal to Own Twitter, Fires CEO and CFO
item.description: The world’s richest man closed his blockbuster purchase of the social media service, thrusting Twitter into a new era.
item.dc:creator: Kate Conger and Lauren Hirsch
item.media:description: Elon Musk agreed to buy Twitter for $44 billion in April.

item.title: Elon Musk Takes Twitter, and Tech Deals, to Another Level
item.description: Silicon Valley moguls used to buy yachts and islands. Now they are rich enough, and perhaps arrogant enough, to acquire companies they fancy.
item.dc:creator: David Streitfeld

item.title: How Twitter Will Change as a Private Company Under Elon Musk
item.description: The social media company went public in 2013. But Elon Musk is taking it private as part of his acquisition of the firm. Here’s what that means.
item.dc:creator: Kate Conger
item.media:credit: Jason Henry for The New York Times
item.media:description: Elon Musk plans to change Twitter from a public to a privately held company.

item.title: The 2022 Race for the House, in Four Districts, and Four Polls
item.description: Swing-district polls by The New York Times and Siena College show how the midterm races are being shaped by larger, surprising forces, beyond the traditional red and blue divide.
item.dc:creator: Shane Goldmacher and Nate Cohn

item.title: In GOP Ad Wars, Trump Takes an Uncharacteristic Supporting Role
item.description: After wielding a bullhorn to shape Republican primaries, the former president has let other groups dominate the airwaves and cover the high cost of commercials.
item.dc:creator: Michael C. Bender
item.media:credit: Rebecca Noble for The New York Times
item.media:description: Former President Donald J. Trump with Blake Masters, the Republican nominee for Senate in Arizona, whose campaign has been a beneficiary of Mr. Trump’s ad spending.

item.title: With Majority in Sight, Republicans Hush Talk of Impeaching Biden
item.description: Party leaders have begun to equivocate about whether they would seek to impeach President Biden if they won a House majority, but pressure is building from those who have vowed to do so.
item.dc:creator: Annie Karni
item.media:credit: Tom Brenner for The New York Times
item.media:description: Representative Kevin McCarthy, the minority leader, has expressed a stance on impeaching President Biden that appears to be at odds with some of the members of his conference.

item.title: Elise Stefanik Believes She Can Turn New York Into a Republican State
item.description: Ms. Stefanik, who leads the House Republican Conference, represents a hard right turn from New York’s tradition of so-called Rockefeller Republicanism.
item.dc:creator: Jesse McKinley
item.media:credit: Cindy Schultz for The New York Times
item.media:description: Representative Elise Stefanik predicts that the Republican Party will win a majority of New York’s 26 House seats in November.

item.title: A Government-Connected Putin Critic’s Flight From Russia Raises Questions About Who is Still Safe.
item.description: Ksenia Sobchak, a socialite who challenged the Russian leader at the polls but at times accommodated his agenda, entered Lithuania this week.
item.dc:creator: Anatoly Kurmanaev
item.media:description: Ksenia Sobchak with President Vladimir V. Putin at the Kremlin in 2018, a day after he won the presidential election, in which she had also been a candidate.

item.title: Many UFO Reports Are Just Spy Drones or Airborne Trash
item.description: Forget space aliens or hypersonic technology; classified assessments show that many episodes have ordinary explanations.
item.dc:creator: Julian E. Barnes
item.category: United States Defense and Military Forces
item.media:credit: Department of Defense, via Agence France-Presse — Getty Images
item.media:description: A video image by Navy pilots of an “unidentified aerial phenomena.”

item.title: Most NYC Job Postings Must Include Salaries Starting in November
item.description: A new city law going into effect on Tuesday will require companies with at least four employees to post salary ranges for openings, even if the jobs involve remote or hybrid work.
item.dc:creator: Matthew Haag
item.media:description: Starting in November a new law in New York City will require job postings in the city to include a salary range.

item.title: ‘No Jobs Available’: The Feast or Famine Careers of America’s Port Drivers.
item.description: Consumer demand has cooled, leaving fewer containers to pick up on the West Coast. For Marshawn Jackson, a truck driver paid by the delivery, that means a hard scrabble to make ends meet.
item.dc:creator: Peter S. Goodman
item.media:credit: Brandon Pavan for The New York Times
item.media:description: Mr. Jackson with his truck in a parking lot in Ontario, Calif.

item.title: For Rail Workers, Anger Persists Over Sick Leave
item.description: A tentative new contract brokered by the White House offered employees one day off, leaving some dissatisfied and raising the risk of another impasse.
item.dc:creator: Peter S. Goodman
item.category: Brotherhood of Maintenance of Way Employees
item.media:credit: Alex Welsh for The New York Times

item.title: The Rising Tide of Global Sadness
item.description: The anger and sadness in culture seems to reflect people’s growing disappointment with their lives.
item.dc:creator: David Brooks
item.category: Blind Spot: The Global Rise of Unhappiness and How Leaders Missed It (Book)

item.title: Elon Musk Is Buying Twitter. Shudder.
item.description: Rogue billionaires have appeared before, and they will appear again. But this one will control our “digital town square.”
item.dc:creator: David Nasaw

item.title: On Affirmative Action, What Once Seemed Unthinkable Might Become Real
item.description: Should diversity still be considered the compelling interest in college admissions that the court said it was in 1978?
item.dc:creator: Linda Greenhouse
item.category: Brown v Board of Education (Supreme Court Decision)

item.title: 二十大“霜降”后，如何度过漫长严冬
item.description: 二十大的结果寒意刺骨，而且预示着仍有漫长的严冬在前方。许多中国人的绝望既来自于对社会发展的迷茫，也来自于个人在社交上的孤立。我们该如何保持希望或者做出反抗？
item.dc:creator: Zhan Juan
item.media:description: 周六，胡锦涛在二十大闭幕会上意外离场。他在被人护送出会场外时停下脚步，与习近平交谈。

item.title: No, That Democrat Didn’t Vote ‘100% of the Time’ With Nancy Pelosi
item.description: G.O.P. operatives, like a classic rock station playing “Stairway to Heaven,” believe that the hits work, and so they eagerly link vulnerable Democrats to the “radical San Francisco liberal.”
item.dc:creator: Blake Hounshell
item.media:credit: Gabriela Bhaskar for The New York Times
item.media:description: Speaker Nancy Pelosi last month. By House tradition, the speaker usually does not vote.

item.title: Taylor Swift’s ‘Midnights’: Let’s Discuss
item.description: The blockbuster singer-songwriter’s 10th studio album finds her at a crossroads: Will she continue to reckon with her past, or forge another new path forward?

item.title: How Much Watching Time Do You Have This Weekend?
item.description: This weekend our TV critic recommends an informative cooking show, an acclaimed limited series and a bittersweet drama.
item.dc:creator: Margaret Lyons
item.category: When You Least Expect It (TV Program)
item.media:description: Christopher Kimball in a scene from “Milk Street’s Cooking School.”

item.title: For Rishi Sunak, Family Wealth From Outsourcing Adds to a Secretive Fortune
item.description: Britain’s new prime minister married into an $800 million stake in Infosys, a company that does not fit neatly into his party’s views on immigration.
item.dc:creator: Jane Bradley
item.media:description: Prime Minister Rishi Sunak of Britain.

item.title: Because of Bolsonaro, Millions of Brazilians Distrust Elections
item.description: President Jair Bolsonaro has attacked Brazil’s electronic voting system. Now, ahead of Sunday’s elections, many of his supporters believe there will be fraud.
item.dc:creator: Jack Nicas
item.media:credit: Maria Magdalena Arrellaga for The New York Times
item.media:description: Mr. Bolsonaro’s supporters focus their attention on a series of anecdotal apparent abnormalities in the voting process and results, as well as many conspiracy theories.

item.title: A Fire, an Arrest, and a New Challenge for the Federal Burn Program
item.description: U.S. Forest Service officials decried the arrest of an employee who was leading prescribed burns in Oregon, where residents accused the agency of reckless burning.
item.dc:creator: Mike Baker
item.media:description: Smoke from a prescribed burn loomed over cattle belonging to the Holliday family near the town of John Day, Ore.

item.title: How to Scan a Leopard Eel for Cancer
item.description: First, get the fish to stay still, all five feet of it.
item.dc:creator: Emily Anthes

item.title: How to Prepare for Daylight Saving Time
item.description: Earlier mornings and shorter evening light can be a tough adjustment. But there are ways to prepare for the end of daylight saving.
item.dc:creator: Holly Burns

item.title: How to Get Back Into Running After a Long Break
item.description: Whether you’re lacing up your running shoes after a few months or a few years, follow these tips to avoid injury and frustration.
item.dc:creator: Knvul Sheikh
item.media:credit: Landon Speers for The New York Times

item.title: The Worst Foods and Drinks for Your Teeth
item.description: When assessing how likely a given meal, snack or drink is to harm your dental health, there are two main things to consider, experts say.
item.dc:creator: Hannah Seo
item.media:credit: Kelsey McClellan for The New York Times

item.title: Is It Covid or the Flu? How to Tell Symptoms Apart
item.description: There are slight differences in symptoms, but the best way to tell which infection you have is through a test.
item.dc:creator: Dani Blum

item.title: How to ‘Romanticize Your Life’
item.description: A trend that took off early in the pandemic encourages people to appreciate life’s simple pleasures, a philosophy that resonates just as strongly two years later.
item.dc:creator: Christina Caron

item.title: This Easy Alfredo Recipe Is Better (and Cheaper) Than Going Out
item.description: This easy, creamy version of the classic fettuccine from Genevieve Ko costs much less than takeout and tastes even better.
item.dc:creator: Genevieve Ko
item.media:credit: Kate Sears for The New York Times. Food Stylist: Hadas Smirnoff.

item.title: How to Solve Hard Crosswords
item.description: Friday, Saturday and Sunday bring some of the hardest puzzles of the week.
item.dc:creator: Jackie Frere and Isaac Aronow
